This was an interactive interview. Although there were questions, the interview was alternative to the common place HR driven variety. I was asked to write a response to a potentially huge customer on behalf of a C level executive. This was a real-life situation and it tested my ability to think on my feet, listen and craft an articulate, simple and info. packed response. I was asked to give an example of "doing the right thing". Moreover, I was asked to interact with different employees in different departments to accomplish small tasks. Additionally, I played the role of a Technical Support Specialist and responded to a mock call with an upset customer calling in.

How will you handle certain situations as a representative because you will run into difficultly customer inevitably.

First role play is individual. The scenario is that you are a rep for B.C and you're at a trade show. You have to present yourself to a new hotel with the objective of getting them to use B.C as their OTA. They currently use a competitor. The key here is to ASK QUESTIONS. As many as you can think of. Don't do what I did and start throwing facts and figures at them. Establish their market and strategy first and apply the facts accordingly. Who is their ideal customer (holiday makers or corporate), what is their main focus (filled rooms of just mere footfall). I couldn't stop talking (and this is why I wasn't hired). As they finish up, try hard to get a meeting scheduled to come and see them at a later date. Be pushy. I wasn't.

The questions are fairly standard and there was nothing that popped out as unusual or overly difficult. In a customer service position you can expect to be asked to role play a difficult call. (They're gauging how pleasant you are, not how knowledgeable you are!) The only question that sort of stood out to me was when I was asked if I had ever been convicted or plead guilty to anything. I answered no honestly, and the interviewer asked me about three more times, as if probing to see if I'd "crack" under the pressure. You will have to pass a criminal background check. It made me feel uncomfortable. Aside from that, it's all pretty standard.

This is the oddest question I got and its the first question they asked me, so right off the bat things were a little strange: "What would make you leave the job right away, if you got the job?" Seemed kind of like a trick question and I'm not entirely sure where it was coming from. Have they had a lot of turnover that they are scared of? If so, should I be asking more questions to figure out why they are so concerned with me leaving right away? What makes anyone leave a job? More money, better opportunities, etc. That's pretty common knowledge, no? Anything beyond that would have to do with the people, the clients and the work environment itself - things I have no idea about in an interview.
How much salary you want

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative was asked...
interview_question: Describe a time when you had to go out of your way for a customer?

"How exactly does [such and such product] work, technically speaking?" I experienced a lot of questions that seemed impossible to answer without working there. The 3 or 4 gentlemen (and it's all men) seemed to get a big kick out of this. They were also talking to each other while I was presenting and one even answered a phone call and stayed in the room! I found it very unprofessional.

They are pretending to be a prospective buyer so they'll ask a lot of questions you won't be able to answer just to fluster you like "how much does the product cost?" and "what is the cost compared to rivals like Cylance, Sophos and Trend Micro?" My group panel seemed distracted during the interview, laughing and sharing text messages while I spoke. It was all very unprofessional.

Following my meeting with the VP and Branch Manager I was asked me to meet some of their internal sales staff - of whom were never available to meet. Following that I found out that there was no position available to begin with of which I confirmed with the people I had initially interviewed. Then I was told by the very same internal recruiter that another Account Manager role had become available in a different division in the same office location and that because I had such a great interview previously that they were actively looking to hire me as an Account Manager. Thus, I went to meet a different VP who stated that we were not discussing the Account Manager role whatsoever and that they were looking for an appointment booker in a junior role. The VP told me he was surprised I would even consider such a role and when I told him that I was there to interview for the Account Manager's role with his team. He stated that no such role existed and expressed to me his anger with the internal recruiter and apologized to me.
They asked me about my sales experience, how I would approach the role, when I was available, what will I bring to the table, why would I want to work there.

The interview was already going sour. No formal greetings. Right into the process of talking about my resume. No problem with that. They questioned everything I said. It felt like an interrogation more than an interview. I contemplated getting up and leaving multiple times but figured I would man up and stick it out. I was asked what I wanted in a company. I mentioned room for growth. They questioned what I meant by "room for growth" within a company. Reasonable question. I mentioned promotions, recognition for work. I was then questioned with what I meant by "promotions." I did not know how to answer an answer that didn't need to be discussed further. They then asked what I knew about the company. I told them everything I knew. They were upset I didn't know more. Told me not to ask about what they do if all of it was available on the internet. They eventually told me I was wasting their time so I walked out. They never discussed what the position entailed or what the company does that I might have missed. Before I walked out, I was scolded and told they pay 90% of benefits, pay $15 an hour, and have a kitchen full of alcohol and food. That is all I ever learned.
What makes you better than the candidate that I interviewed an hour ago?
What are 3 questions about my business that you have for me?

Not one. It was "We love your resume, have checked out your references, want you on XYZ team but XYZ isn't here today. How about we set an appointment for tomorrow?" Tomorrow came and the appointment was pushed back because XYZ was busy. Same with the next day and the next. Then it all went dark. No further contact. From the outside looking in, 180Fusion appears to have it together and very capable. From the inside looking out, it was a mess. While waiting for an interview I was within a couple of feet (no wall separating us) from a manager chewing out an employee for bad language and mistreating another employee. Fair enough other than the manager was choosing equally poor words and was clearly uncomfortable, causing an unprofessional conversation. Additionally, why was this happening in large glass foyer where anyone within 50' could hear the dressing-down?

For the customer service interview, they wanted you to read one of their scripts which described in a clear way what service was being offered to the caller, a number of important disclosures and a check to make sure the customer understood the content. It was a test to see how you might sound on a live call. There weren't any curve balls and they wanted you to know about the company, the daily routine, training available and possibilities for upward/lateral movement within the company. Promoting from within was an important point for me, among others.

the thing that sticks out most in my head was question number 1 why do you want to drive I had my explanation we went back and forth and then we came to the conclusion of I would be better off in a sales environment. The second question that was asked of me was to sell them a car, since I have a car background of over 8 years. I had asked what the scenario was, the manager explained that he could get the same vehicle 2000 dollars cheaper from a different place but the question was why would I want to buy from you. so I naturally gave my first response on how I would sell anything, within 6 to 7 seconds he clapped his hands and said to stop and that I had nailed the question right on the head.
